instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00163: What is 820-00163? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor to components that create power rails for the GPU. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
Hi everyone.
I need help, please.

This mac came as no power after battery run out.
Opened and found a little corrosion on the board due to humidity and dust.
All cleaned, and I found <CAPACITOR>C9327</CAPACITOR> 0 <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> shorted to ground, so CAP replaced, and then I found <CHIP>U8001</CHIP> shorting <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> to ground, <CHIP>U8001</CHIP> replaced and short is gone.
Problem is after I plug the charger I heard a pop somewhere on the board. I've inspected visually the whole board and no burn marks.

Now I have 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> -3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - Cycling 2.75V to 5V

On <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> - cycling
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> - 16.52V
PDCINVSENS_EN_L_DIV - Cycling 8V, 12V and 16.6V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - Cycling 0V to 3V

I just have no idea where else to check.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
"On <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> - cycling
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> - 16.52V"
Not sure what this meant; isn't the same power rail?

F7140/41 still good, for sure?
Check diode mode to ground on all big coils.
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> - 16.59V steady(I mixed up with another line on my previous post)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> -  pulsing
F7140/41 still good

Coils Measurements in diode mode:
L3095 - 0.539
L7720 - 0
L7195 - 0.338
L7520 - 0.366
L7130 - 0.458
L7430 - 0.265
L7630 - 0.122
L7870 - 0.334
L7560 - 0.146
L8710 - 0.193
L8760 - 0.215
L9410 - 0.165
L9330 - 0.049
L9360 - 0.049
L7310 - 0.027
L7320 - 0.027
L7330 - 0.027

I found corrosion and burn mark inside the J3200 (port next to the screen) on the pin that connects to pin 40 on the board. But it's not shorted. But it's missing voltage on that line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
Try to distinguish between voltage and diode mode checkings; STOP to post "V" for diode mode readings.

"the pin that connects to pin 40 on the board"
Why should we need to open boardview and find which pin corresponds in schematic?
YOU are the one working with the board.
We only need to check the schematic.
Please post accurate information.

Apart of L7560, no other big coil pulsing voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
PIN 40 on Thunderbolt port is related to the line <SIGNAL>PP3V3RHV_S4_TBTAPWR_F</SIGNAL> this is 0V at the moment.

L7560 - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> -  pulsing
L7430 - <SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> - pulsing between 0.10V to 0.15V
L7195 - <SIGNAL>P5V1_SW</SIGNAL> - 5.51V steady
L7130 - <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> - 12.55V steady

All the other coils has 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
"L7430 - <SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> - pulsing between 0.10V to 0.15V"
Cannot really consider as pulsing.

You should check for pulse at L7520 first.
Check for short all outputs from page 66.
You should compare readings with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> Cycling
threads.message:
I've missed this <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground.
Basically all CPU phases mosfets, <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and a few more components that get <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is dead.
Applying 1V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Chipset <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> gets hot.
I guess this is beyond repair, as I don't have the right tools to replace the chipset.

Thanks for your help.
